abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            with project sustainability, likely. Overall World Bank
            performance is satisfactory, although uneven. Borrower
            performance is considered satisfactory. Following are some
            of the lessons learned: The implementation capacity of the
            Borrower proved insufficient--smaller steps or a more
            compact project would help avoid such implementation
            bottlenecks. A project not firmly placed within a coherent
            health policy designed by the Borrower will have more of a
            physical rather than institutional impact, which reinforces
            yet again the importance of government ownership in
            project-financed activities. Public information and
            dissemination of project activities and progress can enhance
            project impact. More importantly, though, a public
            information campaign can increase project ownership by
            making the government more accountable to its citizens.
            Lastly, the sustainability of training activities is linked
            to proper selection of participants. That is, lower and
            middle level staff are less likely to be laid off when a new
            government comes to office. Thus, knowledge remains in the
            system. In contrast, top management is vulnerable to changes
            in government.

5082181.trustfund:
TF023330-SIDA CTF FOR EASTERN EUROPE,TF025610-HEALTH SERVICES PLANNING AND MGMT.,TF033120-POLAND - HEALTH PROJECT,TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF026080-USTDP ENVIRONMENTAL
            CONSL'T TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will support the
            government's economic refrom program by improving
            health, strengthening the health sector's contribution
            to the social safety net, and containing upward pressure
            from the health sector on the state budget. To achieve these
            goals, the project will: (a) improve health status by
            strengthening health promotion and prevention programs; (b)
            support the first steps in restructuring the health sector
            by shifting the focus from institutional care to effective
            primary care through better trained primary care doctors and
            nurses; (c) strengthen institutional capacity in policy
            making, planning, management and evaluation by providing
            managers access to improved infromation systems and
            management education; and (d) ensure sustainability of
            services and control costs in the health sector in the
            medium-term by improving effectiveness, efficiency and
            quality of service delivery in three project regions. The
            project comprises four components: (a) health promotion; (b)
            primary health care; (c) health management; and (d) regional
            health services. For each, it will provide technical
            assistance, training, equipment and civil works.
